desc: The SPRED1 gene encodes a member of the Sprouty family of proteins. SPRED1 is a negative regulator of the MAP-kinase (MAPK) pathway (PMID: 15683364, 21364986). The mechanism by which SPRED1 inhibits MAPK signaling involves NF1 (neurofibromatosis type 1), which, upon interaction with SPRED1, localizes to the plasma membrane and facilitates RAS inactivation (PMID: 22751498, 26635368). Overexpression of SPRED1 in a hepatocellular carcinoma model leads to a decrease in cell motility and an increase in the expression of metalloproteinases, which are involved in invasion and metastasis (PMID: 16652141). SPRED1 is rarely mutated in cancers (cBioPortal, MSKCC, Dec. 2016). However, germline loss-of-function mutations in SPRED1 are the cause of Legius syndrome, a familial disorder with neurofibromatosis-like features (PMID: 24334617, 17704776, 19366998).

articles.title: Germline loss-of-function mutations in SPRED1 cause a neurofibromatosis 1-like phenotype.
articles.reference: Brems H et al. Nature genetics. 2007 Sep;39(9)1120-6.

desc: SPRED1, a negative regulator of the MAP-kinase pathway, is mutated at low frequencies in various cancers.
